title: R43398
content: The federal government has supported educational statistics for over 150 years, with the creation of the National Institute of Education and the National Center for Education Statistics in the 1970s. The Institute of Education Sciences now oversees federal educational research and statistics efforts. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) replaced OERI in 2002 through the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA). ESRA established IES as an independent research institute within the Department of Education, headed by a Director appointed by the President. A technical panel, the National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES), advises the Director on policies, research priorities, and conducts assessments. Three National Education Centers were established to focus on research in different areas. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) as an independent research institute within the Department of Education. It created three National Education Centers: the National Center for Education Research (NCER), the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), and the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance (NCEE). P.L. 108-446 added a fourth center, the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER). Additionally, P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) to support technical assistance activities and assessments. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) as an independent research institute within the Department of Education. It created three National Education Centers and added a fourth center later. P.L. 107-279 enacted the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) to support technical assistance activities and assessments. ESRA led to the creation of an independent research institute and specified "scientifically-based" or "scientifically-valid" standards for research. IES operates independently with more freedom from the Department of Education. ESRA established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) as an independent research institute within the Department of Education, providing more freedom from ED. It also introduced greater oversight through a technical panel (NBES) and specified standards for educational research. Funding for ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA programs continued post FY2008. The House and Senate passed bills to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending provisions related to IES research standards, evaluation, privacy protection, and accountability. Funding for these programs has continued through annual appropriations legislation. The report provides a concise description of programs and authorities established by ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA as amended under P.L. 107-279. It discusses recent legislative action and Title I of P.L. 107-279, which is the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) that establishes IES as a research institute within ED. The aim of IES is to provide information on education progress and practices that improve academic achievement. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) provides information on education progress, academic achievement, and federal education programs. The IES Director is appointed by the President and carries out duties such as proposing research priorities and ensuring activities are objective and free of political influence. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) authorizes the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the IES Director on research priorities, funding decisions, and the improvement of IES. ESRA specifies requirements for Board members' composition and qualifications. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) outlines requirements for the Board of IES, including composition, qualifications, compensation, and travel expenses. IES consists of four research centers, each with specific duties as outlined in ESRA. Three centers are headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Director, while the fourth center's Commissioner is appointed by the President. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) is one of the four research centers under the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA). NCER's mission is to sponsor research that ensures all children have access to quality education, improves academic achievement, closes achievement gaps, and promotes postsecondary education opportunities. NCER also supports research synthesis, promotes scientific inquiry practices, and maintains peer-review processes. The National Center for Education Research (NCER), outlined in ESRA, maintains peer-review processes and standards for research. The Commissioner is authorized to support national research centers focusing on various education topics. The National Center for Education Research (NCER) supports research centers addressing national education needs through competitive grants. Awards are given for up to five years, with the possibility of continuation grants for up to 10 years. The Commissioner of NCER oversees a research plan that includes basic, applied, and field-initiated research efforts. At least 50% of funds each year are allocated to long-term research programs lasting five years or more. ESRA Part C authorizes the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) to collect and analyze education information. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information and statistics to fund long-term research programs of not less than five years. NCES reports education information objectively, neutrally, and free of partisan political influence, ensuring relevance to practitioners, researchers, policymakers, and the public. Other duties include publishing reports on collected statistics and determining voluntary standards for state educational agencies. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information, publish reports on statistics, determine standards for state educational agencies, and provide information on student achievement compared to other nations. The Commissioner of NCES can award grants, contracts, and provide technical assistance for these duties. Certain data must be collected on topics such as education reform activities, student achievement in reading, math, and science, school completions, dropouts, teaching practices, and teacher supply and demand. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information, including data on dropouts, adult literacy skills, teaching practice, violence affecting students, financing and management of education, social and economic status of children, educational technology, early childhood programs, vocational education, school libraries, and more. Data must be disaggregated by various demographic factors. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information, including data on various demographic factors. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support evaluation, technical assistance, and dissemination activities to facilitate educational and policy decision making. NCEE's mission is to provide technical assistance, conduct evaluations of federal education programs, support synthesis and dissemination of results, and encourage the use of valid education research throughout the United States. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) is authorized to collect and analyze education information, including data on various demographic factors. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support evaluation, technical assistance, and dissemination activities to facilitate educational and policy decision making. NCEE's mission is to provide technical assistance, conduct evaluations of federal education programs, support synthesis and dissemination of results, and encourage the use of valid education research throughout the United States. The Commissioner of NCEE is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements, establish evaluation methodology, and ensure evaluations adhere to high standards of quality. NCEE evaluates programs under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) and provides technical assistance primarily through the Regional Educational. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects education data, while the National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) supports evaluation and technical assistance for federal education programs. NCEE works through the Regional Educational Laboratories (REL) program to provide training and assistance to education agencies on ESEA implementation and research. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) work with education agencies to provide training and assistance on ESEA implementation and research. Their duties include facilitating communication between educational experts and school officials, conducting applied research, and disseminating promising educational practices. The Commissioner of NCEE oversees independent evaluations of each REL and reports the results to relevant committees. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) sponsors research to improve outcomes for children with disabilities and evaluates the implementation of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). NCSER's duties include enhancing services under IDEA, identifying effective practices for academic achievement, and promoting participation in general education settings. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) focuses on improving outcomes for children with disabilities by identifying effective interventions, aligning state standards, addressing overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, improving personnel preparation, and addressing the special needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities through grants, contracts, and research activities. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) is responsible for setting standards for research activities and disseminating findings. ESRA Part F outlines provisions for funding, data availability, staffing, and appropriations. Funding for ESRA and Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) was authorized for FY2003 and subsequent years. Despite the expiration of these authorities in FY2008, funding has continued through annual appropriations legislation. Title II of P.L. 107-279, known as the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA), authorizes grants for technical assistance and evaluation to local entities and states for data systems. The Secretary can award grants for comprehensive centers in 10 regions to provide training and support for ESEA programs. The Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) authorizes grants for comprehensive centers to provide training, professional development, and technical assistance for ESEA programs. Each center must coordinate activities with local entities, establish an advisory board, and report annually to the Secretary. The Secretary conducts independent evaluations and reports to congressional committees and the Director of IES. Competitive grants are also available for SEAs to design data systems. The ETAA authorizes grants for comprehensive centers to provide training, professional development, and technical assistance for ESEA programs. The Secretary conducts evaluations and reports to congressional committees. Competitive grants are available for SEAs to design data systems. Funding has continued through annual appropriations legislation. The National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) established the National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) and charges the Commissioner of Education Statistics with conducting the NAEP assessments. NAEP includes national and state assessment programs, a long-term trend study, and a trial urban district assessment program. The national assessment program evaluates student achievement in reading and mathematics every two years for grades 4 and 8. States can choose to participate in the state assessment program. The National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) oversees the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) assessments, which include national and state programs for grades 4 and 8 in reading and mathematics. States can opt to participate in the state assessment program. Participation in NAEP assessments is voluntary for students, schools, and local educational agencies. The Assessment Board, comprising various stakeholders, formulates policy guidelines for NAEP. The Assessment Board sets duties for NAEP, including selecting subject areas, developing achievement levels, test specifications, and involving stakeholders in the assessment process. The National Assessment Governing Board and NAEP conduct large scale surveys to measure student academic achievement in grades 4, 8, and 12. They develop guidelines for reporting results and standards for comparisons. Funding for these activities has been ongoing through annual appropriations legislation. Funding for education research has been ongoing through annual appropriations legislation. In the 113th and 114th Congress, bills were passed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, with proposed changes to IES independence, research standards, evaluation, and accountability. Both bills aimed to give the Director of IES more authority and responsibilities. Both bills proposed giving the Director of IES more authority by allowing them to appoint the Commissioner of NCES and amending provisions for the appointment and term limits of the IES Director. They also aimed to make NBES independent of the Director and required at least two board members to be practitioners knowledgeable about US education needs. The bills proposed giving the Director of IES more authority, including the ability to appoint the Commissioner of NCES and serve for an additional year if a successor is not appointed. They also required the involvement of the Director or designee in procurement processes and established a peer review system for grants and contracts exceeding $100,000. The bills proposed changes to the award process for IES grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements, requiring them to be awarded through a peer review process. They also aimed to redefine "scientifically based research standards" as "principles of scientific research" and specified criteria for research designs to support strong claims of causal relationships. Additionally, the bills adjusted the specified topical research priorities for IES. The bills proposed changes to the award process for IES grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements, requiring a peer review process. They aimed to redefine "scientifically based research standards" as "principles of scientific research" and specified criteria for research designs to support strong claims of causal relationships. The bills were more explicit in specifying that designs would not be limited to random assignment experiments and adjusted the specified topical research priorities for IES. Some narrowly targeted priorities under current law would no longer be specified, and the requirement for a specific number of national research and development centers supported by NCER would be eliminated. The bills proposed changes to the mission and structure of RELs, limiting their number to not more than 10 and focusing on conducting applied research, development, evaluation, and dissemination activities. The Evaluation and Regional Assistance Commissioner would have the authority to determine the appropriate number of RELs and reorganize them based on needs. The bills proposed changes to the mission and structure of RELs, limiting their number to not more than 10. The Evaluation and Regional Assistance Commissioner would have the authority to determine the appropriate number of RELs and reorganize them based on needs. H.R. 4366 and S. 227 would assign technical assistance responsibility to ED-administered Comprehensive Centers, with a limit of 17 awards in H.R. 4366 and a set number of 17 in S. 227. The Secretary would have the authority to determine the number of centers in consultation with advisory boards. The bills proposed changes to the mission and structure of RELs, limiting their number to not more than 10. The Evaluation and Regional Assistance Commissioner would have the authority to determine the appropriate number of RELs and reorganize them based on needs. The Secretary would have the authority to determine the number of centers in consultation with advisory boards, with a limit of 17 awards. Both bills aimed to ensure rigor and independence in research and evaluations of federal education programs. The bills proposed changes to the evaluation of programs authorized under ESEA, including reserving funds for evaluations and requiring a biennial evaluation plan to be submitted to Congress. Additionally, the role of the National Assessment Governing Board would be amended to "oversee and set policies" for the NAEP. The bills proposed changes to the evaluation of programs authorized under ESEA, including reserving funds for evaluations and requiring a biennial evaluation plan to be submitted to Congress. The National Assessment Governing Board's role would be amended to "oversee and set policies" for the NAEP. Both bills aimed to improve activities and fund utilization through measurable performance indicators and triennial or five-year evaluations of National Education Centers. Both bills proposed changes to the evaluation of programs authorized under ESEA, including tying renewal of grants to progress on measurable indicators. The Director would have authority to renew support for research centers and Statistics Commissioner for up to two years. Recipients of renewal awards would need to demonstrate progress in meeting performance management system requirements. The awards show progress in meeting ESRA's performance management system requirements. The bills authorize renewal of support without competition for up to two years. Recipients must demonstrate progress in meeting performance management system requirements. The Director must report grant information to the public within 120 days. Regulatory requirements on data access by federal agencies and interested parties would be codified. Appropriations for ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA would be authorized at specific levels for FY2015 through FY2020. Both bills would authorize specific levels of appropriations for ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA for FY2015 through FY2020, rather than the current practice of authorizing funds for the first fiscal year and subsequent years as needed. Additionally, the bills would reserve 16.13% of ESRA funds for the RELs, instead of the current fixed amount of $100,000 for FY2003 and subsequent years.
